oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The significance of mycorrhizal fungi for crop productivity and ecosystem sustainability in organic farming systems
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: van der Heijden, Dr. Marcel
Rinaudo, Mrs Valeria
Verbruggen, Mr. Erik
Scherrer, Mr. Caroline
Bàrberi, Prof. Paolo
Giovannetti, Prof. Manuela
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soil biology
Biodiversity and ecosystem services
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mycorrhizal fungi are widespread in agricultural systems and are especially relevant for organic agriculture because they can act as natural fertilisers, enhancing plant yield. Here we explore the various roles that mycorrhizal fungi play in sustainable farming systems with special emphasis on their contribution to crop productivity and ecosystem functioning. We review the literature and provide a number of mechanisms and processes by which mycorrhizal fungi can contribute to crop productivity and ecosystem sustainability. We then present novel results, showing that mycorrhizal fungi can be used to suppress several problematic agricultural weeds. Our results highlight the significance of mycorrhizal fungi for sustainable farming systems and point to the need to develop farming systems in which the positive effect of these beneficial soil fungi is optimally being utilized.
